  [2025 Nasser Hospital strikes](/wiki/2025_Nasser_Hospital_strikes "2025 Nasser Hospital strikes")<br>    <br><br>* * *<br><br>[War crimes and effects](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "War crimes in the Gaza war")<br><br>*   [War crimes and crimes against humanity report](/wiki/Diplomatic_impact_of_the_Gaza_war#Independent_International_Commission_of_Inquiry_on_the_Occupied_Palestinian_Territory_report "Diplomatic impact of the Gaza war")<br>    <br>*   [Palestinian war crimes](/wiki/Palestinian_war_crimes "Palestinian war crimes")<br>    *   [Hostage crisis](/wiki/Gaza_war_hostage_crisis "Gaza war hostage crisis")<br>        *   [2023 prisoner exchange](/wiki/2023_Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_prisoner_exchange "2023 Israeli–Palestinian prisoner exchange")<br>            <br>*   [Israeli war crimes](/wiki/Israeli_war_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "Israeli war crimes in the Gaza war")<br>    *   [Israeli blockade of Gaza](/wiki/Israeli_blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip (2023–present)")<br>        *   [Famine](/wiki/Gaza_Strip_famine "Gaza Strip famine")<br>            <br>    *   [AI-assisted targeting](/wiki/AI-assisted_targeting_in_the_Gaza_Strip "AI-assisted targeting in the Gaza Strip")<br>        <br>    *   [Mass detentions](/wiki/Mass_detentions_in_the_Gaza_war "Mass detentions in the Gaza war")<br>        <br>    *   [South Africa v. It began on 5 October 2024 when the [Israel Defense Forces](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces")
 (IDF) reinvaded [Jabalia](/wiki/Jabalia "Jabalia")
 and [its refugee camp](/wiki/Jabalia_refugee_camp "Jabalia refugee camp")
 for the first time in months since [earlier fighting](/wiki/Battle_of_Jabalia "Battle of Jabalia")
.[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)
[\[9\]](#cite_note-bbc.com-9)

The siege was reportedly part of Israel's "[generals' plan](/wiki/Israeli_generals%27_plan "Israeli generals' plan")
" to force Palestinians out of northern Gaza by designating it a combat zone and issuing [evacuation orders](/wiki/Gaza_Strip_evacuations "Gaza Strip evacuations")
 to civilians under threat of death.[\[19\]](#cite_note-:4-19)
 The IDF imposed a complete siege on northern Gaza, cutting it off from [Gaza City](/wiki/Gaza_City "Gaza City")
 by destroying most of the roads leading south and preventing the [entry of aid](/wiki/Humanitarian_aid_during_the_Gaza_war "Humanitarian aid during the Gaza war")
.[\[20\]](#cite_note-Stray_dogs-20)
[\[21\]](#cite_note-21)
 Evacuations were hindered, however, by [Israeli bombardments](/wiki/Israeli_bombing_of_the_Gaza_Strip "Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip")
 and [shootings of fleeing civilians](/wiki/Attacks_on_protected_zones_and_civilians_in_Gaza "Attacks on protected zones and civilians in Gaza")
, leaving many trapped.[\[22\]](#cite_note-Thousands_trapped_in_Jabalia_camp-22)
 Human rights groups raised concerns of [war crimes](/wiki/Israeli_war_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "Israeli war crimes in the Gaza war")
, and Israeli actions were characterized as ethnic cleansing and [genocide](/wiki/Gaza_genocide "Gaza genocide")
.[\[23\]](#cite_note-Dead_bodies_everywhere-23)
[\[24\]](#cite_note-24)
 Israel [attacked hospitals](/wiki/Attacks_on_health_facilities_during_the_Gaza_war "Attacks on health facilities during the Gaza war")
 and [medical infrastructure](/wiki/Attacks_on_health_facilities_during_the_Gaza_war "Attacks on health facilities during the Gaza war")
, as international bodies warned of disastrous conditions in Jabalia.[\[25\]](#cite_note-Last_remaining_hospitals_in_North_Gaza-25)

Israel's siege extended to Beit Lahia and Beit Hanoun, with officials stating no food had been allowed to enter either town or Jabalia.[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)
 A senior [COGAT](/wiki/Coordinator_of_Government_Activities_in_the_Territories "Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories")
 official stated that aid delivery was being confined to Gaza City because there was "no population" remaining in Beit Lahia and Beit Hanoun.[\[27\]](#cite_note-27)

A [ceasefire](/wiki/2025_Gaza_war_ceasefire "2025 Gaza war ceasefire")
 between Israel and Hamas came into effect on 19 January 2025, with the IDF withdrawing from northern Gaza to a buffer zone along the [Gaza Strip–Israel border](/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Israel_barrier "Gaza–Israel barrier")
 on that same day.[\[28\]](#cite_note-:5-28)

Background
----------

Further information: [Battle of Beit Hanoun](/wiki/Battle_of_Beit_Hanoun "Battle of Beit Hanoun")
 and [Battle of Jabalia](/wiki/Battle_of_Jabalia "Battle of Jabalia")

Fighting between Palestinian militants and the IDF had taken place in [Beit Hanoun](/wiki/Beit_Hanoun "Beit Hanoun")
 and Jabalia since 27 October 2023 and 8 November 2023, respectively.[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)
[\[6\]](#cite_note-:0-6)
 The IDF also launched raids into [Beit Lahia](/wiki/Beit_Lahia "Beit Lahia")
 such as the [Kamal Adwan Hospital sieges](/wiki/Kamal_Adwan_Hospital_sieges "Kamal Adwan Hospital sieges")
 in December 2024 and May 2024.[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)
[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)
[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)

The IDF encountered "significant resistance" during the [fighting in Jabalia](/wiki/Battle_of_Jabalia "Battle of Jabalia")
[\[6\]](#cite_note-:0-6)
 and ultimately failed to dismantle Hamas' presence in the city.[\[33\]](#cite_note-:6-33)

On 31 May 2024, the IDF withdrew from North Gaza, including both Beit Hanoun and Jabalia.[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)
[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)

In the four months since the Israeli withdrawal, Hamas reportedly reconstituted itself in Jabalia and managed to recruit thousands of new fighters in the area.[\[6\]](#cite_note-:0-6)
 Hamas also planted explosives in almost all buildings in Jabalia, sometimes even causing the death of its own militants.[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)

Siege
-----

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Merkava_of_Beit_Hanoun.jpg/250px-Merkava_of_Beit_Hanoun.jpg)](/wiki/File:Merkava_of_Beit_Hanoun.jpg)

Israeli soldiers inspecting a [Merkava](/wiki/Merkava "Merkava")
 that was destroyed by Hamas in [Beit Hanoun](/wiki/Beit_Hanoun "Beit Hanoun")

### Jabalia

On the evening of 5 October,[\[4\]](#cite_note-:dateclarification1-4)
[\[5\]](#cite_note-:dateclarification2-5)
 the IDF began its stated operation to dismantle Hamas control in Jabalia, with the [Israeli Air Force](/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force "Israeli Air Force")
 launching strikes around the area while armored brigades encircled the [Jabalia refugee camp](/wiki/Jabalia_refugee_camp "Jabalia refugee camp")
.[\[6\]](#cite_note-:0-6)

The IDF advanced into Jabalia and were met by combined attacks from Hamas, [Palestinian Islamic Jihad](/wiki/Palestinian_Islamic_Jihad "Palestinian Islamic Jihad")
 (PIJ), [al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades](/wiki/Al-Aqsa_Martyrs%27_Brigades "Al-Aqsa Martyrs' Brigades")
, and the [Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine](/wiki/Popular_Front_for_the_Liberation_of_Palestine "Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine")
 (PFLP).[\[6\]](#cite_note-:0-6)
 PIJ launched an attack on an Israeli [command and control room](/wiki/Command_center "Command center")
 belonging to forces attempting to penetrate the Jabalia refugee camp.[\[37\]](#cite_note-:1-37)

On 10 October, Hamas organized an ambush which destroyed an IDF mechanized infantry company of 12 vehicles east of the Jabalia camp.[\[38\]](#cite_note-:2-38)
[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)
[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)
 The IDF said that an Israeli airstrike on a Hamas command and control centre killed at least 12 Hamas and PIJ commanders.[\[38\]](#cite_note-:2-38)

On 13 October, Israeli prime minister [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
 stated that the IDF had reached "the heart of Jabalia" and were dismantling Hamas strongholds there. He is considered to have been the highest-ranking officer to have died in ground combat since the start of the Gaza war.[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)
[\[46\]](#cite_note-46)

On 22 October, Hamas said that its fighters detonated an explosive device targeting 12 Israeli soldiers in the Jabalia refugee camp, killing and wounding some of them.[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)

On 17 November, Israeli media reported that that IDF soldiers preparing an ambush in southern Jabalia were themselves ambushed by Hamas fighters.[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)

On 20 December, a Hamas fighter carried out a suicide bombing against an IDF position in the Jabalia camp.[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)

On 30 December, Palestinian militants carried out a "relatively large attack" in multiple waves against IDF positions around the Jabalia camp.[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)

### Beit Lahia

On 11 October, clashes between the IDF and Hamas were reported to be taking place in Beit Lahia.[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)
 Palestinian health officials stated on 27 October that Israeli strikes had killed at least 87 people.[\[52\]](#cite_note-52)
 On 28 October, an Israeli attack on the Beit Lahia residential square reportedly killed 45 people, with more than 30 trapped under the rubble.[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)
 After residents of Jabalia fled to Beit Lahia, the IDF then reportedly turned their attention to the town.[\[54\]](#cite_note-54)
 Sam Rose, a UN official, stated, "People who fled to Beit Lahiya have themselves been bombed".[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)
 Beit Lahia declared a state of emergency due to Israel's siege and attacks, stating, "We declare that the city is a disaster area due to the Israeli war of extermination and siege, and it has no food, water, hospitals, doctors, services, or communications".[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)

Five people were reportedly killed by Israeli airstrikes in Beit Lahia on 1 November.[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)
 Rescue teams were also attacked, with three members hit by a drone, while the civil defence stated an Israeli tank destroyed their only fire truck.[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)
 At least twenty people were reportedly killed during an attack on 4 November, with video showing residents pulling bodies out of the rubble.[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)

On 23 December, Hamas said that some of its fighters stormed an IDF position at a building in Beit Lahia and managed to free several Palestinians who had been detained inside.[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)

### Beit Hanoun

In Beit Hanoun, the IDF conducted bombings on the night of 11–12 November and targeted fleeing civilians with drones and sniper fire the next day.[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)
 The IDF besieged some 130 families in a shelter in the city and forced them to leave at gunpoint.[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)

Despite claiming to have “dismantled Hamas” in Beit Hanoun, Israeli forces who entered the abandoned city on 23 December were immediately ambushed by militants. We can’t get out."[\[80\]](#cite_note-80)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/NetzarimCorridor.jpg/330px-NetzarimCorridor.jpg)](/wiki/File:NetzarimCorridor.jpg)

Approximate location of the [Netzarim Corridor](/wiki/Netzarim_Corridor "Netzarim Corridor")
.

According to Israeli media, tens of thousands of Palestinians have passed through the IDF security crossing at the [Netzarim Corridor](/wiki/Netzarim_Corridor "Netzarim Corridor")
 to get to the southern Gaza Strip.[\[41\]](#cite_note-:3-41)
 On 7 October 2024, however, UN Spokesperson [Stéphane Dujarric](/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Dujarric "Stéphane Dujarric")
 stated many people in northern Gaza were "trapped" in their homes and that "few families have crossed Wadi Gaza heading South".[\[81\]](#cite_note-81)
 [Doctors Without Borders](/wiki/Doctors_Without_Borders "Doctors Without Borders")
 stated at least five of their staff members were trapped in Jabalia, stating, "Nobody is allowed to get in or out; anyone who tries is getting shot".[\[22\]](#cite_note-Thousands_trapped_in_Jabalia_camp-22)
 [UNRWA](/wiki/UNRWA "UNRWA")
 head [Philippe Lazzarini](/wiki/Philippe_Lazzarini "Philippe Lazzarini")
 stated, "People attempting to flee are getting killed, their bodies left on the street".[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)

Anas al-Sharif, a journalist on the ground, stated that possibly thousands of families were "trapped between tanks, their gunfire, and heavy artillery shelling".[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)
 One woman stated she was forced from her home "at gunpoint" as tanks and heavily armed soldiers encircled her family, and that young men were separated for interrogation.[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)
 Another woman stated that in Jabalia, a quadcopter told residents: "Don't think of north Gaza ever again."[\[85\]](#cite_note-Under_deadly_Israeli_siege-85)
 Israeli footage showed men separated at checkpoints in northern Gaza and possibly detained.[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)
 The Israeli military released footage of Palestinians being rounded up near the besieged Indonesia Hospital, where they had been sheltering.[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)
[\[88\]](#cite_note-88)
 Residents stated Israeli forced stormed shelters for displaced families and detained men, with footage showing men sitting next to a tank while others were led away by a soldier.[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)
 The UN Human Rights Office stated it was concerned the men could be subject to arbitrary detainment and torture.[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)

### Targeting of civilians

Per the [Palestinian Civil Defense](/wiki/Palestinian_Civil_Defence "Palestinian Civil Defence")
, at least 17 people, including 9 children, were killed in the IDF's initial wave of airstrikes.[\[37\]](#cite_note-:1-37)
 One of those killed was journalist Hassan Hamad, who was reportedly deliberately targeted by Israel after receiving threats via messages and calls from Israeli officers, ordering him to stop his reporting.[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)
 After an Israeli airstrike on 11 October that killed at least 22 Palestinians and wounded more than 90, Hamas made a statement the following day condemning what it described as the "[Nazi](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism")
 occupation’s massacres" in Jabalia under [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")
 protection.[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)
 Journalists stated they were being directly targeted by the Israeli army, including Fadi Al Wahidi, who was reportedly shot in the neck by a sniper.[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)

On 14 October, [Al Jazeera Arabic](/wiki/Al_Jazeera_Arabic "Al Jazeera Arabic")
 reported the Israeli military was planting explosives in homes to demolish them.[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)
 The same day, medics reported that Israeli forces fired on civilians waiting for flour at a food distribution centre, killing ten people and wounding dozens.[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)
 On 16 October, the Gaza Civil Defense stated there were dozens of people trapped under the rubble, and some bodies were laying in the road unable to be rescued.[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)
 Gaza's civil defence agency spokesman stated, "There are a number of pleas from families being bombed inside Jabalia camp... The remaining soldiers were then attacked by Hamas militants who opened fire on them before withdrawing, wounding a further six.[\[70\]](#cite_note-70)

Evacuation and attacks on civilians
-----------------------------------

### Generals' plan

Main article: [Israeli generals' plan](/wiki/Israeli_generals%27_plan "Israeli generals' plan")

On 6 October 2024, Israel designated all of the northern Gaza Strip as a combat zone and ordered the entire civilian population to evacuate.[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)
[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)
 Both Israeli military analysts and the [Al-Mezan Center for Human Rights](/wiki/Al-Mezan_Center_for_Human_Rights "Al-Mezan Center for Human Rights")
 alleged that this was the first stage of the "[generals' plan](/wiki/Israeli_generals%27_plan "Israeli generals' plan")
", a policy proposed by former Israeli general [Giora Eiland](/wiki/Giora_Eiland "Giora Eiland")
 to force Palestinians out of Gaza on pain of death.[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)
 The Israeli human rights organizations [Gisha](/wiki/Gisha_(human_rights_organization) "Gisha (human rights organization)")
, [B'Tselem](/wiki/B%27Tselem "B'Tselem")
, [Physicians for Human Rights](/wiki/Physicians_for_Human_Rights%E2%80%93Israel "Physicians for Human Rights–Israel")
 and [Yesh Din](/wiki/Yesh_Din "Yesh Din")
 stated there were "alarming signs" that Israel was implementing the plan.[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)
 Three Israeli reserve soldiers in Gaza stated it was their understanding the general's plan was being practically implemented.[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)
 The plan has been described by Hamas as [genocidal](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide")
.[\[19\]](#cite_note-:4-19)
 Others have described the plan as the [ethnic cleansing](/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing "Ethnic cleansing")
 of northern Gaza.[\[23\]](#cite_note-Dead_bodies_everywhere-23)
 The United Nations warned that Israel was not allowing food to enter northern Gaza or Jabalia.[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)
[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)

On 7 October, the IDF issued evacuation orders for residents of Jabalia, Beit Hanoun, and Beit Lahia, instructing them to travel southwards to the [al-Mawasi humanitarian zone](/wiki/Al-Mawasi,_Rafah "Al-Mawasi, Rafah")
.[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)
 Following these evacuation orders was made more difficult by Israel's ongoing bombardment, as well as drones pursuing and shooting at individuals attempting to flee.[\[79\]](#cite_note-79)
 Residents reported being trapped in Jabalia, with all roads blocked except the main highway leading out. Then, they stormed the area with their tanks and opened fire randomly."[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)
 At least 87 people were killed by an [airstrike in Beit Lahia](/wiki/October_2024_Beit_Lahia_attacks "October 2024 Beit Lahia attacks")
.[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)

On 21 October, 10 people were reportedly killed and 30 wounded by an Israeli attack at the Jabalia Preparatory School turned shelter.[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)
 A paramedic fleeing the shelter stated that people were attempting to comply with an evacuation order when "suddenly there was shelling".[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)
[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)
 On 23 October, civil defence teams stated they were attempting to rescue people buried under rubble by hand.[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)
 The same day, three civil defense workers were wounded in a "targeted strike" by Israel, leading the agency to suspend operations in northern Gaza.[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)
 Israeli forces also reportedly killed northern Gaza's chief of police.[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)
 The civil defense reported 150 people were killed and injured in an airstrike on Jabalia's Block 7 on 24 October.[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)
 Dozens were killed by Israeli strikes on residences in Beit Lahia on 26 October.[\[114\]](#cite_note-114)
 As many as 93 people were killed by an [Israeli airstrike on Beit Lahia](/wiki/29_October_2024_Beit_Lahia_strike "29 October 2024 Beit Lahia strike")
 on 29 October.[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)

On 1 November 2024, the Gaza Government Media Office reported two Israeli airstrikes on residential buildings killed 84 people, including 50 children.[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)
 The civil defense stated they were unable to reach the site and residents were attempting rescues.[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)
 Women evacuating from Jabalia stated the Israeli army forced them into holes, where dust was thrown on them as an intimidation tactic.[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)

Dr. stated Israel had "failed to implement" their recommendations, and that it would "follow the law" if Israel did not comply by its deadline.[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)

### Hospitals and healthcare

During the siege, the Health Ministry stated Israel was "intensifying its targeting of the health system in the northern Gaza Strip".[\[103\]](#cite_note-Israeli_air_strike_kills_33-103)
 WHO's vaccination campaign to address Gaza's [polio epidemic](/wiki/2024_Gaza_Strip_polio_epidemic "2024 Gaza Strip polio epidemic")
 was delayed in northern Gaza due to the escalating violence and intense bombing.[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)
 On 9 October, an Israeli airstrike killed at least 15 people inside Al-Yemen Al-Saeed Hospital in Jabalia, which has housed displaced families.[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)
 Israel reportedly used a "double tap" bombing, injuring fifteen people in a family home, then targeted an ambulance arriving to help them, killing a doctor.[\[138\]](#cite_note-138)

The Gaza Health Ministry stated Israel had besieged and was directly targeting the [Indonesia Hospital](/wiki/Indonesia_Hospital "Indonesia Hospital")
, Kamal Adwan Hospital, and [Al-Awda Hospital](/wiki/Al-Awda_Hospital "Al-Awda Hospital")
.[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)
 More than 350 patients were reportedly trapped in the three hospitals, including pregnant women, people with chronic health conditions, and individuals needing surgeries.[\[25\]](#cite_note-Last_remaining_hospitals_in_North_Gaza-25)
 The Al Awda hospital stated Israeli strikes on the hospital and an ambulance had wounded several medical staff.[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)
 In a statement, the director of Al-Awda Hospital stated, "Israeli forces are targeting everything that moves in northern Gaza".[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)

#### Indonesia Hospital

The Indonesia Hospital's director stated, "Israeli tanks have completely surrounded the hospital, cut off electricity and shelled the hospital, targeting the second and third floors with artillery".[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)
 Staff reported heavy gunfire directed at the hospital, with more than 40 patients injured.[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)
 Two patients at Indonesia Hospital were reported to have died after the hospital lost electricity, as the UN stated the Indonesia Hospital was no longer operational.[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)
[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)
 Indonesia Hospital's chief nurse stated the hospital's water supply had been cut, that operating the electric generator required permission from the IDF, and there was no food available for four consecutive days.[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)
 On 21 October 2024, medics at Indonesia Hospital stated Israeli forces set a nearby school on fire, which spread to the hospital and shut down its power.[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)

#### Kamal Adwan Hospital

On 25 October 2024, Israel launched [a raid of Kamal Adwan Hospital](/wiki/Kamal_Adwan_Hospital_sieges#October_and_November_2024 "Kamal Adwan Hospital sieges")
.[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)
 The Palestinian health ministry stated 600 patients, companions, and staff were trapped.[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)
 The following day, the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization")
 stated that while the hospital was still under siege, it had regained contact with its employees there, stating that four employees were injured, 44 health workers had been detained, and four ambulances were damaged.[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)
 The Gaza Ministry of Health stated that Israeli forces had detained all male medical staff.[\[151\]](#cite_note-151)
 On 27 October, Dr. Retrieved 2025-01-22.

Retrieved from "[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Siege\_of\_North\_Gaza&oldid=1307670532](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Siege_of_North_Gaza&oldid=1307670532)
"

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article discusses the Siege of North Gaza, which began on October 5, 2024, and ended on January 19, 2025, with a ceasefire. The location of the siege was in the North Gaza Governorate, Gaza Strip, Palestine. The article mentions that on October 10, Hamas organized an ambush which destroyed an IDF mechanized infantry company of 12 vehicles east of the Jabalia camp. The article also mentions that on October 17, the Israeli air force bombed the Abu Hussein school.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

## Elaboration
The image search results show other images of burning tanks, but they do not confirm the details of the claim. The geolocation data suggests the image could have been taken in Palestine or Israel, but this is not definitive. The evidence does not provide enough information to verify the claim.

The claim mentions an ambush by Hamas fighters near Jabalia camp in northern Gaza in October 2024. The evidence does not contain any information about the date, location, or the actors involved in the event.

Three partially functioning hospitals treating severely wounded patients and sheltering thousands of displaced Palestinian civilians in northern Gaza are now out of service after coming under intense Israeli fire, a Gaza health official told Al Jazeera, as [the siege on Jabalia](/news/2024/10/12/several-killed-in-israeli-strikes-on-northern-gazas-jabalia)
 enters its third week, with at least 33 more people killed in the northern area.

[Israeli forces](/news/liveblog/2024/10/19/live-israeli-attack-kills-at-least-33-in-north-gazas-jabalia-refugee-camp)
 bombed al-Awda Hospital in Jabalia early on Saturday, and have also shelled Kamal Adwan and the Indonesian hospitals in Beit Lahiya over the past few hours, Al Jazeera correspondents have reported.

“We cannot count the number of those killed. Witnesses also told Abu Azzoum the situation in other parts of Jabalia had “severely deteriorated” since Friday.

“They said that they are surrounded by Israeli tanks and that destruction is everywhere. At least 85 others were wounded, some critically, raising fears of more fatalities.

The Israeli military said its operation in Jabalia is intended to stop Hamas fighters regrouping for more attacks. The numbers are terrifying,” the official told Al Jazeera.

At least one person has been killed and several others were wounded in the strike at the entrance of the laboratory of Kamal Adwan Hospital, Gaza’s Health Ministry said.

The Palestinian news agency Wafa also reported that because of the military siege, two intensive care unit patients at the Indonesian Hospital have died on Saturday.

In another Israeli attack on central Gaza’s Maghazi refugee camp, at least 16 people were killed, the Palestinian official news agency WAFA said on Saturday, adding that there are still missing people under the rubble.

At least seven people were also reported killed in a separate Israeli strike on a school sheltering Palestinian refugees in al-Shati camp, just west of Jabalia. In Jabalia itself, an air strike on Saturday afternoon killed five more people.

Another four people were reported killed in another Israeli strike in al-Nuseirat refugee camp, according to our Al Jazeera team from Gaza.

In Rafah city, southern Gaza Strip, two people were killed in an Israeli drone airstrike on the Khirbet area.

In all, the death toll has surpassed the 67 killed in [Israeli attacks across Gaza](/tag/israel-palestine-conflict/)
 in the last 24 hours, as earlier reported by health authorities in the enclave. At least 450 have been killed since the siege began two weeks ago.

Al Jazeera’s Tarek Abu Azzoum, reporting from Deir el-Balah in central Gaza, said witnesses in northern Gaza told him the second and third floors of the Indonesian Hospital, as well as its courtyard, have been hit, resulting in “a number of casualties”.

At least 40 patients are trapped inside the hospital and Israeli tanks have surrounded it, he said.

Meanwhile, the attack on al-Awda Hospital cut power to the medical facility."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israel-kills-least-40-gaza-tanks-deepen-raid-north-2024-10-15/): 
Content: "[Skip to main content](#main-content)

[Exclusive news, data and analytics for financial market professionalsLearn more aboutRefinitiv](/differentiator/)

*   Summary

*   Israeli strikes kill 50 Palestinians in Gaza
*   Israeli forces tighten siege around Jabalia
*   Israel says it is facilitating humanitarian aid to Jabalia
*   Says it has helped to transfer patients and staff from the north to other hospitals

CAIRO, Oct 15 (Reuters) - Israeli military strikes killed at least 50 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip as Israeli forces tightened their squeeze around Jabalia in the north of the enclave on Tuesday, amid fierce battles with Hamas-led fighters.

Palestinian health officials said at least 17 people were killed by Israeli fire near Al-Falouja in Jabalia, the largest of Gaza's eight historic refugee camps, while 10 others were killed in Bani Suhaila in eastern Khan Younis in the south when an Israeli missile struck a house.

Sign up [here.](undefined?location=article-paragraph&redirectUrl=%2Fworld%2Fmiddle-east%2Fisrael-kills-least-40-gaza-tanks-deepen-raid-north-2024-10-15%2F)

Earlier on Tuesday, an Israeli airstrike destroyed three houses in the Sabra suburb of Gaza City, and the local civil emergency service said they recovered two bodies from the site, while the search continued for 12 other people who were believed to have been in the houses at the time.

Eight others were killed when a house was struck in the Nuseirat camp in central Gaza.

The Gaza health ministry said one doctor was killed when he tried to help people wounded by Israeli strikes in Al-Falouja in Jabalia. It said it was facilitating humanitarian, and in particular medical aid to residents.

!Aftermath of Israeli strike on a tent camp sheltering displaced people in Gaza's Al-Mawasi <image:9643>

Item 1 of 5 Palestinians inspect the damage at the site of an Israeli strike on a tent camp sheltering displaced people, amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict, in Al-Mawasi area in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, October 15, 2024. REUTERS/Hatem Khaled

**\[1/5\]**Palestinians inspect the damage at the site of an Israeli strike on a tent camp sheltering displaced people, amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas conflict, in Al-Mawasi area in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, October 15, 2024. REUTERS/Hatem Khaled [Purchase Licensing Rights, opens new tab](https://www.reutersconnect.com/item/aftermath-of-israeli-strike-on-a-tent-camp-sheltering-displaced-people-in-gazas-al-mawasi/dGFnOnJldXRlcnMuY29tLDIwMjQ6bmV3c21sX1JDMlVLQUFVOVNLNg%3D%3D/?utm_medium=rcom-article-media&utm_campaign=rcom-rcp-lead)

Hamas denies it embeds its operatives amongst civilians.

JABALIA ENCIRCLED
-----------------

The Israeli military has now encircled the Jabalia camp and sent tanks into nearby Beit Lahiya and Beit Hanoun towns, with the declared aim of stamping out Hamas fighters who are trying to regroup there.

The Israeli military has told residents to leave their homes and head to safety in southern Gaza. It added that several medics were wounded when their ambulance came under Israeli fire in the northern and southern Gaza Strip.

Jabalia has been the focus of an Israeli offensive for more than 10 days, with troops returning to areas of the north that came under [heavy bombardment](https://www.reuters.com/graphics/ISRAEL-PALESTINIANS/ANNIVERSARY-GAZA-RUBBLE/akveegbnlvr/)
 in the early months of the [year-long war.](https://www.reuters.com/world/israel-hamas/)

The operation has raised concerns among Palestinians and U.N. Residents said Israeli forces destroyed dozens of houses in the past 10 days.

On Tuesday, the Israeli military said troops had killed dozens of fighters in the Jabalia area over the past day, including a unit that fired an anti-tank missile at them.

The United Nations human rights office said the Israeli military appeared to be "cutting off North Gaza completely from the rest of the Gaza Strip."

"Gaza families are facing unimaginable fear, loss of loved ones, confusion, and exhaustion. officials say there is no safe place in Gaza.

Hamas' armed wing said fighters were engaged in fierce battles with Israeli forces in and around Jabalia.

Gaza's health ministry said the army ordered the three hospitals operating there to evacuate but medical staffers said they were determined to continue their services.

Cogat said in recent days it had facilitated the transfer of 33 patients, medical staff and accompanying personnel from the Kamal Adwan Hospital in the north to functioning facilities elsewhere in Gaza.

It said it has also provided 68,650 litres of fuel to hospitals and coordinated the delivery of 800 blood transfusion units.

Ismail Al-Thawabta, the director of the Hamas-run Gaza government media office, said Israel was trying to give a misleading impression and that its forces had been preventing ambulance and civil emergency teams from recovering the bodies of dozens of people from the streets.

Hussam Abu Safiya, director of Kamal Adwan Hospital, one of the three hospitals in northern Gaza, said they were facing serious shortages of food, medication, and fuel, that could soon impact patients in their facilities.

"There is a stark shortage of consumables and supplies began to run out. People must be able to flee safely, without facing further danger," Adrian Zimmerman,

ICRC Gaza head of sub-delegation, said in a statement.

The Israeli military's administrative unit, Cogat, which oversees aid and commercial shipments to Gaza, said on Tuesday that operations in Jabalia were targeting terrorist infrastructure and operatives embedded inside civilian areas. Around 400,000 people remain, according to United Nations estimates.

Israel launched the offensive against Hamas after the militant group's Oct. 7 attack on Israel, in which 1,200 people were killed and around 250 taken hostage to Gaza, by Israeli tallies."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Reuters reports on October 15, 2024, that Israeli military strikes killed at least 50 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip, with Israeli forces tightening their squeeze around Jabalia. The article mentions fierce battles with Hamas-led fighters in and around Jabalia. <image:9643> shows the aftermath of an Israeli strike on a tent camp sheltering displaced people in Gaza's Al-Mawasi area in Khan Younis on October 15, 2024.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:34> This image shows an Israeli tank unit near Jabalia camp in northern Gaza that was successfully ambushed by Hamas fighters, destroying multiple vehicles and injuring or killing their crews in October 2024."

## Actions
```
image_search("burning tank Israeli army")
geolocate(<image:34>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
Sky News shows an image of a burning tank (<image:9603>). The website vpk.name also shows an image of a burning tank (<image:9604>).

The source kashif.ps discusses an old photo being circulated as showing the destruction of an Israeli military tank (<image:9605>).


### Evidence from `geolocate`
The most likely countries where the image was taken are: {'Pakistan': 0.11, 'Palestine': 0.11, 'Israel': 0.1, 'Tunisia': 0.09, 'Mexico': 0.06, 'Colombia': 0.05, 'Chile': 0.04, 'Sweden': 0.03, 'Argentina': 0.02, 'Denmark': 0.02}

## Elaboration
The image search results show other images of burning tanks, but they do not confirm the details of the claim. The geolocation data suggests the image could have been taken in Palestine or Israel, but this is not definitive. The evidence does not provide enough information to verify the claim.

The claim mentions an ambush by Hamas fighters near Jabalia camp in northern Gaza in October 2024. The evidence does not contain any information about the date, location, or the actors involved in the event.

To verify the claim, information about the specific event, including the date, location, and the parties involved, is needed.


## Actions
```
web_search("Hamas ambush Israeli tank Jabalia October 2024")
web_search("Israeli tank destroyed Gaza October 2024")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_North_Gaza): 
Content: The Wikipedia article discusses the Siege of North Gaza, which began on October 5, 2024, and ended on January 19, 2025, with a ceasefire. The location of the siege was in the North Gaza Governorate, Gaza Strip, Palestine. The article mentions that on October 10, Hamas organized an ambush which destroyed an IDF mechanized infantry company of 12 vehicles east of the Jabalia camp. The article also mentions that on October 17, the Israeli air force bombed the Abu Hussein school.


From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/19/hospitals-in-northern-gaza-under-israeli-fire-as-jabalia-attack-kills-33): 
Content: Al Jazeera reports on an Israeli army operation in the Jabalia refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip on October 18, 2024, amid the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas. The report mentions that at least 33 people were killed in the northern area. The report also mentions that Israeli forces have been advancing further into the center of Jabalia and fighting with Hamas forces. <image:9606>, <image:9607>. The article was published on October 19, 2024.


From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israel-kills-least-40-gaza-tanks-deepen-raid-north-2024-10-15/): 
Content: Reuters reports on October 15, 2024, that Israeli military strikes killed at least 50 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip, with Israeli forces tightening their squeeze around Jabalia. The article mentions fierce battles with Hamas-led fighters in and around Jabalia. <image:9643> shows the aftermath of an Israeli strike on a tent camp sheltering displaced people in Gaza's Al-Mawasi area in Khan Younis on October 15, 2024.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_North_Gaza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_North_Gaza)) discusses the Siege of North Gaza, which began on October 5, 2024, and mentions an ambush by Hamas on October 10, 2024, that destroyed an IDF mechanized infantry company east of the Jabalia camp. Al Jazeera ([https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/19/hospitals-in-northern-gaza-under-israeli-fire-as-jabalia-attack-kills-33](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/19/hospitals-in-northern-gaza-under-israeli-fire-as-jabalia-attack-kills-33)) reports on an Israeli army operation in the Jabalia refugee camp on October 18, 2024, and Reuters ([https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israel-kills-least-40-gaza-tanks-deepen-raid-north-2024-10-15/](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israel-kills-least-40-gaza-tanks-deepen-raid-north-2024-10-15/)) reports on October 15, 2024, about Israeli strikes and fierce battles with Hamas-led fighters in and around Jabalia. The Al Jazeera article includes images of the destruction in Jabalia (<image:9606>, <image:9607>), and the Reuters article includes an image of a tent camp (<image:9643>).

* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

From [Source](https://www.bbc.com/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t): 
Content: "Summary
-------

*   UN peacekeepers in southern Lebanon [say an Israeli tank has again fired at one of its watchtowers](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3Ad7243836-9c98-4a20-b14d-38f59395a8a4#post)
     in a "direct and apparently deliberate" attack
    
*   The UN says two cameras were destroyed and the tower damaged at one of its positions in southern Lebanon - it follows several reports of similar incidents over the past week
    
*   In Gaza, more lorries carrying aid [have reached the north](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3Aced6029b-9a5b-4716-a20b-c9650abced5c#post)
     for the third day running - after a period of two weeks without aid deliveries
    
*   [Fighting continues in Gaza,](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3A7e0b3723-fb9d-4a08-9913-a1c673ee5e56#post)
     as well as southern Lebanon where authorities say 16 people, including the local mayor, were killed by [Israeli air strikes on a council building in the city of Nabatieh](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3Ae04cd359-51ea-44c2-8feb-0b9397c48cb3#post)
    
*   Israel also hit Beirut for the first time in five days, while Hezbollah [has fired more rockets into northern Israel,](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3Aa769426b-c768-4b8d-89dc-2965bf0dd19c#post)
     with at least two people injured
    

Live Reporting
--------------

Edited by Tinshui Yeung and Francesca Gillett with Riam El Dalati and Joel Gunter in Lebanon, and Yolande Knell in Jerusalem

1. They say that this morning, peacekeepers at a position near Kafer Kela, a village in southern Lebanon, saw an Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) tank firing at their watchtower.
    
    Unifil says that two cameras were destroyed and the tower was damaged in what they call "direct and apparently deliberate fire on a Unifil position".
    
    The IDF has not yet commented.
    
    On Sunday, Unifil has also said [two Israeli tanks destroyed the main gate](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cwylekwngz8o)
     of a post in Ramyah, and "forcibly entered the position".
    
    [Tensions between Israel and the UN over peacekeeping operations](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/ce9j74z7xvmo)
     in southern Lebanon have been rising recently.
    
    In the latest standoff, the head of UN peacekeeping operations rejected a call on Monday by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for Unifil to pull out of “combat areas”.

    Image caption,
    
    Israel has been urged to do more to ensure humanitarian aid reaches communities in need across the Gaza Strip
    
    Israel disputes the UN figures but [even its data shows just 39 lorries a day entered, external](https://gaza-aid-data.gov.il/main/)
     in the first 12 days of October, with the highest number of 226 a day entering in April.
    
    Israel has previously insisted there are no limits to the amount of aid that can be delivered into and across Gaza and blames UN agencies for failing to distribute supplies. **Israeli tank fired at peacekeeper watchtower – Unifil**
    
    The UN Interim Force in Lebanon (Unifil) said an Israeli tank fired at their watchtower, describing it as "apparently deliberate fire" at its position – Israel is yet to comment.
    
    It follows several reports of similar incidents over the past week – you can read our Middle East correspondent [Wyre Davies' in-depth look at the row between the two here.](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/ce9j74z7xvmo)
    
    **Cross-border fire continues**
    
    Lebanon says 16 people were killed in an [Israeli strike on a municipal building in Nabatieh](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cy43z81nnvlo)
    , a city in the south, with the mayor among those killed – Israel said it was targeting Hezbollah in the area.
    
    Israel also carried out air strikes on Beirut early this morning for the first time in five days.
    
    Meanwhile, the Israel Defense Forces said 90 projectiles were fired at Israel in the last 24 hours, and emergency services there said two people were treated after being injured. Lebanon's government reported 138 strikes in the past 24 hours, state media reports.
    
    **Mounting pressure over Gaza**
    
    After Washington demanded Israel allow more aid into Gaza or risk a reduction in military support, Reuters and Israel's Channel 13 News reported that Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu has convened an emergency meeting to address the situation.
    
    Our international editor Jeremy Bowen [writes that the US threat is a sign of its anger that Israel has not kept its promises.](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c3e9q4nylwjo)
    
    We're closing this page now. !A view shows damaged buildings following an Israeli military strike in Qana, southern Lebanon <image:9657>Image source, EPA
    
    Image caption,
    
    A picture taken earlier today shows some of the damage following a strike in Qana, southern Lebanon
    
    The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) say they've "eliminated" the leader of a Hezbollah unit in Qana, Lebanon, where Israel carried out overnight strikes.
    
    According to the IDF, the Israeli Air Force struck Jalal Mustafa Hariri and other Hezbollah members responsible for artillery and anti-tank missiles in the Qana region.
    
    It's unclear if the [strikes in Qana last night](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3A2ed7d92b-f3b2-4e89-9855-a9edc5f2ea9d#post)
     were the ones that killed Hariri or how many other members of the armed group were killed. Earlier this evening, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convened an emergency meeting to discuss increasing humanitarian aid entering the Gaza Strip, Reuters and Israel's Channel 13 News are reporting.
    
    It comes after Israel received a strongly-worded letter from the United States about the humanitarian situation in Gaza and as the UN Security Council met in New York to discuss it.
    
    Following Netanyahu's meeting, three Israeli officials told Reuters aid is expected to increase in the near future. They also rely on the **Kerem Shalom crossing**, near Egypt.
    
    Two other crossings - **Erez** in the north, and **Rafah** in the south - **are closed**.
    
    According to the most recent update from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), which is responsible for humanitarian affairs, 96% of Gazans are facing crisis levels of food insecurity, with nearly 500,000 people facing catastrophic food insecurity.
    
    !A map of Israel and the Gaza Strip shows where aid can move into the enclave <image:9663>

     for delays in getting vital supplies into the area.
    
    Israeli UN envoy Danny Danon says his country "remains committed" to ensuring aid reaches Palestinians.
    
    Still, Gaza [faces a critical shortage](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/cjwdx0y5nj9t?post=asset%3A29bc0cc5-5352-44c0-a7f8-e4faa1df423f#post)
    : Prior to the conflict, 500 lorries per day entered Gaza with supplies. After months of Hezbollah attacks, on 1 October the Israeli military launched a wave of air strikes and a [ground invasion of southern Lebanon](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/czxgyzq7z2ro)
    .

Strength[![Israel](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Flag_of_the_Israel_Defense_Forces.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Israel_Defense_Forces.svg.png)](/wiki/Israel "Israel")

300+ Popular Forces militants[\[d\]](#cite_note-55)

 20,000–40,000+ fighters[\[52\]](#cite_note-56)
  
![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Emblem_of_the_Palestinian_Civil_Police_Force.png/40px-Emblem_of_the_Palestinian_Civil_Police_Force.png)~9,000 policemen[\[53\]](#cite_note-npr.org-57)
Casualties and losses

*   **Per Israel:**
*   459–887+ killed[\[e\]](#cite_note-61)
    
*   2,800+ wounded[\[57\]](#cite_note-IDFlist2025-62)
    
*   1 [UH-60 Black Hawk](/wiki/Sikorsky_UH-60_Black_Hawk "Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk")
     Helicopter crashed[\[58\]](#cite_note-IDFHeli-63)
    
*   1 [Sikorsky CH-53](/wiki/Sikorsky_CH-53 "Sikorsky CH-53")
     Helicopter shot down[\[59\]](#cite_note-64)
    
*   1 [Elbit Skylark](/wiki/Elbit_Skylark "Elbit Skylark")
     drone malfunctioned and seized by Palestinians[\[60\]](#cite_note-65)
    
*   **Per Al-Qassam Brigades:**
*   1,600+ killed[\[61\]](#cite_note-66)
    
*   3,400+ wounded[\[62\]](#cite_note-maariv-67)
    
*   1+ captured[\[63\]](#cite_note-aljazeera.net-68)
    \[_[need quotation to verify](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")\
    _\]
*   1,108+ [armored vehicles](/wiki/Armored_vehicles "Armored vehicles")
     destroyed or disabled[\[64\]](#cite_note-69)
    
*   70+ Popular Forces militants killed[\[f\]](#cite_note-73)
    

*   **Per the US:**
*   10,000–15,000 Hamas fighters killed[\[68\]](#cite_note-74)
    
*   **Per Israel:**
*   8,000–20,000 militants killed[\[69\]](#cite_note-75)
    [\[70\]](#cite_note-76)
    [\[71\]](#cite_note-77)
    [\[72\]](#cite_note-78)
    
*   ~2,500 militants captured[\[73\]](#cite_note-GallantKhanYunis-79)
    
*   ~15,000 militants wounded[\[74\]](#cite_note-Yonah-80)
    
*   **Per [Palestinian Police](/wiki/Palestinian_Civil_Police_Force "Palestinian Civil Police Force")
    :**
*   1,400+ policemen killed[\[75\]](#cite_note-81)
    [\[53\]](#cite_note-npr.org-57)
    

46,707 Palestinians killed, 110,265 injured (Per the [Gaza Health Ministry](/wiki/Gaza_Health_Ministry "Gaza Health Ministry")
)[\[76\]](#cite_note-AlJazeera_DeathToll20250115-82)
[\[77\]](#cite_note-Reuters_DeathToll20250115-83)
  
More than 70,000 Palestinians killed from traumatic injuries alone (Per [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet "The Lancet")
)[\[78\]](#cite_note-CNN_Lancet2025-84)
  
Indirect deaths[\[g\]](#cite_note-86)
 likely to be several times higher than those killed by violence, with estimates for total Palestinian deaths in the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
 at 186,000[\[80\]](#cite_note-87)
 or 335,500[\[h\]](#cite_note-89)
  
32,331 Palestinian civilians killed, 60,128 Palestinians injured (Per Euro-Med Monitor)[\[82\]](#cite_note-EMD-90)
[\[83\]](#cite_note-91)
  
75 hostages killed (per Israel)[\[84\]](#cite_note-92)

  [2025 Nasser Hospital strikes](/wiki/2025_Nasser_Hospital_strikes "2025 Nasser Hospital strikes")<br>    <br><br>* * *<br><br>[War crimes and effects](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "War crimes in the Gaza war")<br><br>*   [War crimes and crimes against humanity report](/wiki/Diplomatic_impact_of_the_Gaza_war#Independent_International_Commission_of_Inquiry_on_the_Occupied_Palestinian_Territory_report "Diplomatic impact of the Gaza war")<br>    <br>*   [Palestinian war crimes](/wiki/Palestinian_war_crimes "Palestinian war crimes")<br>    *   [Hostage crisis](/wiki/Gaza_war_hostage_crisis "Gaza war hostage crisis")<br>        *   [2023 prisoner exchange](/wiki/2023_Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_prisoner_exchange "2023 Israeli–Palestinian prisoner exchange")<br>            <br>*   [Israeli war crimes](/wiki/Israeli_war_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "Israeli war crimes in the Gaza war")<br>    *   [Israeli blockade of Gaza](/wiki/Israeli_blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip (2023–present)")<br>        *   [Famine](/wiki/Gaza_Strip_famine "Gaza Strip famine")<br>            <br>    *   [AI-assisted targeting](/wiki/AI-assisted_targeting_in_the_Gaza_Strip "AI-assisted targeting in the Gaza Strip")<br>        <br>    *   [Mass detentions](/wiki/Mass_detentions_in_the_Gaza_war "Mass detentions in the Gaza war")<br>        <br>    *   [South Africa v. Israel's campaign has four stated goals: to destroy [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
, to free [the hostages](/wiki/Israeli_hostages_in_Gaza "Israeli hostages in Gaza")
, to ensure Gaza no longer poses a threat to Israel, and to return displaced residents of Northern Israel.[\[85\]](#cite_note-Invasion-93)
[\[86\]](#cite_note-Invasion1-94)
[\[87\]](#cite_note-Goals-95)
[\[88\]](#cite_note-96)
 More than a year after the invasion, fighting in the Gaza Strip halted with the implementation of [a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas](/wiki/2025_Israel%E2%80%93Hamas_war_ceasefire "2025 Israel–Hamas war ceasefire")
 on 19 January 2025.

By April 2025, the [Gaza Ministry of Health](/wiki/Gaza_Ministry_of_Health "Gaza Ministry of Health")
 had reported that at least 50,500 people in the Gaza Strip had died—1 out of every 44 people—averaging 93 deaths per day.[\[89\]](#cite_note-97)
 Most of the victims are civilians,[\[90\]](#cite_note-98)
[\[91\]](#cite_note-The_Guardian_15_August_2024-99)
 of whom at least 50% are [women](/wiki/Women_in_the_Gaza_war#Gaza_Strip "Women in the Gaza war")
 and [children](/wiki/Effect_of_the_Gaza_war_on_children_in_the_Gaza_Strip "Effect of the Gaza war on children in the Gaza Strip")
.[\[92\]](#cite_note-100)
[\[93\]](#cite_note-101)
 Compared to other recent global conflicts, the numbers of known deaths of journalists, humanitarian and health workers, and children are among the highest.[\[94\]](#cite_note-102)
 Thousands of more dead bodies are thought to be under the rubble of destroyed buildings.[\[91\]](#cite_note-The_Guardian_15_August_2024-99)
[\[95\]](#cite_note-103)
 A study in _[The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet "The Lancet")
_ estimated 64,260 deaths due to traumatic injuries by June 2024, while noting a larger potential death toll when "indirect" deaths are included.[\[96\]](#cite_note-Lancet2025-104)
[\[97\]](#cite_note-Bloxham_Mar_2025-105)
 As of January 2025, a comparable estimate for traumatic injury deaths would be around 80,000.[\[97\]](#cite_note-Bloxham_Mar_2025-105)
 The number of injured is greater than 100,000;[\[98\]](#cite_note-106)
 Gaza has the most child amputees per capita in the world.[\[99\]](#cite_note-107)

A severe [humanitarian crisis](/wiki/Gaza_humanitarian_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Gaza humanitarian crisis (2023–present)")
 has developed, with healthcare on the brink of collapse,[\[100\]](#cite_note-108)
 shortages of food, clean water, medicine and fuel due to the blockade,[\[101\]](#cite_note-109)
[\[102\]](#cite_note-Rushdi-110)
[\[103\]](#cite_note-111)
 electricity and communications blackouts,[\[104\]](#cite_note-112)
 and the UN warning of potential [famine](/wiki/Gaza_Strip_famine "Gaza Strip famine")
.[\[105\]](#cite_note-113)
 It was widely reported that there is "no safe place in Gaza", as Israel struck areas it had previously told Palestinians to evacuate to.[\[106\]](#cite_note-114)
[\[107\]](#cite_note-115)
[\[108\]](#cite_note-116)
 Nearly all 2.3 million Gazans have been [internally displaced](/wiki/Internally_displaced "Internally displaced")
[\[109\]](#cite_note-117)
 and 250,000 to 500,000 Israelis were internally displaced,[\[110\]](#cite_note-118)
[\[111\]](#cite_note-119)
[\[112\]](#cite_note-120)
 while Israel has [detained](/wiki/Mass_detentions_in_the_2023_Israel%E2%80%93Hamas_war "Mass detentions in the 2023 Israel–Hamas war")
 thousands of Palestinians[\[113\]](#cite_note-AI0-121)
[\[114\]](#cite_note-122)
[\[115\]](#cite_note-123)
 and said it lost 353 additional soldiers in its invasion as of 13 October 2024.[\[116\]](#cite_note-124)
 By mid-December, Israel had dropped 29,000 munitions on Gaza, destroying or damaging 70 percent of homes, destroying hundreds of cultural landmarks, and damaging dozens of cemeteries.[\[117\]](#cite_note-125)
[\[118\]](#cite_note-TG111-126)
[\[119\]](#cite_note-AlJazeera_heritage_sites_Jan24-127)
[\[120\]](#cite_note-cnn111-128)
 Experts say that the scale and pace of destruction in Gaza is among the most severe in recent history.[\[121\]](#cite_note-Burke_2023-129)
[\[122\]](#cite_note-130)

The widespread civilian [deaths](/wiki/Casualties_of_the_Gaza_war "Casualties of the Gaza war")
 have led to [accusations of war crimes](/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Gaza_war "War crimes in the Gaza war")
 against both Israel and Hamas.[\[123\]](#cite_note-131)
[\[124\]](#cite_note-Corder-2023-132)
 As a result of the invasion, South Africa instituted [proceedings](/wiki/South_Africa_v._Israel_(Genocide_Convention) "South Africa v. [Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press")
 reported that Israeli airstrikes also destroyed roads leading to the Al-Shifa hospital, making it increasingly difficult to reach.[\[156\]](#cite_note-164)
 Later in the day, Hamas said that Palestinian militants clashed with Israeli tanks in [Salah al-Din Street](/wiki/Salah_al-Din_Street "Salah al-Din Street")
 in Gaza and forced the IDF to retreat.[\[157\]](#cite_note-165)
 The [Institute for the Study of War](/wiki/Institute_for_the_Study_of_War "Institute for the Study of War")
 also said that Israel withdrew from the road.[\[158\]](#cite_note-ISW-166)

#### 30 October

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Images_of_war_23-25_from_Gaza%2C_by_Jaber_Badwen%2C_IMG_6185.jpg/250px-Images_of_war_23-25_from_Gaza%2C_by_Jaber_Badwen%2C_IMG_6185.jpg)](/wiki/File:Images_of_war_23-25_from_Gaza,_by_Jaber_Badwen,_IMG_6185.jpg)

Tents staked in an area of northern Gaza that was flattened by the Israeli military

The IDF blocked the [Salah al-Din Road](/wiki/Salah_al-Din_Road "Salah al-Din Road")
, a major thoroughfare connecting the northern and southern parts of the Gaza Strip. But it also noted that the rate of Hamas deaths was falling as Hamas reduced head-on assaults against the IDF and became more reliant on underground tunnels.[\[445\]](#cite_note-453)

In advance of ground operations on 7 October, Israel assassinated Hamas commanders throughout Gaza, including [Ali Al Qadi](/wiki/Ali_Al_Qadi "Ali Al Qadi")
 and [Ayman Nofal](/wiki/Ayman_Nofal "Ayman Nofal")
.

During the invasion of the Gaza strip, Palestinians fighting against the Israeli occupation damaged or destroyed a large number of Israeli tanks, causing a shortage of both tanks and ammunition for the IDF.[\[446\]](#cite_note-454)

Strategy
--------

### Israeli strategy

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%97%D7%95%D7%AA_%D7%A6%D7%94%D7%9C_%D7%9E%D7%AA%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%9C%D7%9B%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%A1%D7%94_%D7%9C%D7%A2%D7%96%D7%94_%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%9D_%D7%99%D7%95%D7%90%D7%91_%D7%A7%D7%A8%D7%9F.jpg/250px-%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%97%D7%95%D7%AA_%D7%A6%D7%94%D7%9C_%D7%9E%D7%AA%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%9C%D7%9B%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%A1%D7%94_%D7%9C%D7%A2%D7%96%D7%94_%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%9D_%D7%99%D7%95%D7%90%D7%91_%D7%A7%D7%A8%D7%9F.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%97%D7%95%D7%AA_%D7%A6%D7%94%D7%9C_%D7%9E%D7%AA%D7%9B%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%9D_%D7%9C%D7%9B%D7%A0%D7%99%D7%A1%D7%94_%D7%9C%D7%A2%D7%96%D7%94_%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%9D_%D7%99%D7%95%D7%90%D7%91_%D7%A7%D7%A8%D7%9F.jpg)

Israeli soldiers in a [Namer APC](/wiki/Namer_APC "Namer APC")
 before invasion of the Gaza Strip

On 29 October, Israeli defense minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 said he expected the "second stage of the war" to last "months". Retrieved 12 February 2024.

[Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")

Part of the [Gaza–Israel conflict](/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Gaza–Israel conflict")
, the [Israeli–Palestinian conflict](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict "Israeli–Palestinian conflict")
, and the [Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)")

 by Israel, and the use of [human shields](/wiki/Use_of_human_shields_by_Hamas "Use of human shields by Hamas")
 and holding of Israeli hostages by Hamas.

Background
----------

Main article: [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")

Further information: [Gaza–Israel conflict](/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Gaza–Israel conflict")

See also: [Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip (2023–present)](/wiki/Israeli_blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip (2023–present)")
 and [Evacuation of the northern Gaza Strip](/wiki/Evacuation_of_the_northern_Gaza_Strip "Evacuation of the northern Gaza Strip")

After Palestinian militant groups led by [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
 launched an [attack on Israel](/wiki/October_7_attacks "October 7 attacks")
 on 7 October 2023 which saw a minimum of 1,139 largely non-combatant individuals killed, Israel [declared war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
 against Hamas.[\[127\]](#cite_note-135)
 Israel moved to mobilize 300,000 [reservists](/wiki/Reserve_duty_(Israel) "Reserve duty (Israel)")
 and began to move armor close to the border with the Gaza Strip in the aftermath.[\[128\]](#cite_note-136)
[\[129\]](#cite_note-Sharma_2023-137)
 Included in the amassing of armor were [Namer](/wiki/Namer "Namer")
 armored personnel carriers and [Merkava](/wiki/Merkava "Merkava")
 tanks.[\[129\]](#cite_note-Sharma_2023-137)

Before the raids, Israel had told the UN that the more than a million people living in the north half of the Gaza Strip should evacuate within a 24-hour window.[\[130\]](#cite_note-138)
 In response, Hamas instructed those residents to stay put.[\[131\]](#cite_note-139)
[\[132\]](#cite_note-Ward_2023-140)
 The [Israel Defense Forces](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces")
 (IDF) had urged around 1.1 million civilians to leave [North Gaza](/wiki/North_Gaza_Governorate "North Gaza Governorate")
 so they would not be hurt or caught in crossfire,[\[133\]](#cite_note-141)
 and Israeli officials said that the window was left at 24-hours to reduce the time for Hamas to conduct military preparation in the area. Anyone who chooses not to evacuate from the North of the Gaza Strip to the South of the Gaza Strip may be identified as a partner in a terrorist organization."[\[135\]](#cite_note-143)
[\[136\]](#cite_note-144)

### Raids inside Gaza

On 13 October 2023, the IDF sent armored vehicles and infantry into the Gaza Strip, stating that their goals were to attack Hamas fighters[\[137\]](#cite_note-toilb13oct-145)
 and to rescue hostages that had been abducted to Gaza by Hamas.[\[137\]](#cite_note-toilb13oct-145)
[\[138\]](#cite_note-146)
 The operation, according to Israeli officials, was not part of a larger and widely anticipated ground invasion, but rather a raid in which troops only temporarily enter the Gaza Strip.[\[139\]](#cite_note-147)
[\[140\]](#cite_note-148)
 The IDF confirmed the same day that Israeli remains were located and retrieved in the Gaza Strip.[\[141\]](#cite_note-149)

Another raid, headed by the [Givati Brigade](/wiki/Givati_Brigade "Givati Brigade")
 and the [162nd Armoured Division](/wiki/162nd_Division_(Israel) "162nd Division (Israel)")
, took place between 25 and 26 October and was the largest offensive so far,[\[142\]](#cite_note-toi26oct-150)
 including tanks, other vehicles and [IDF Caterpillar D9](/wiki/IDF_Caterpillar_D9 "IDF Caterpillar D9")
 armored bulldozers.[\[143\]](#cite_note-151)
 A follow-up raid took place the next night in the [Shuja'iyya](/wiki/Shuja%27iyya "Shuja'iyya")
 neighborhood of Gaza City.[\[144\]](#cite_note-152)

October–November 2023: invasion begins
--------------------------------------

### October 2023

#### 27 October

Internet and mobile phone services in Gaza were nearly cut off.[\[145\]](#cite_note-153)
[\[146\]](#cite_note-154)
 On the evening of 27 October, the IDF launched a large-scale ground assault on the towns of [Beit Hanoun](/wiki/Beit_Hanoun "Beit Hanoun")
 and [Bureij](/wiki/Bureij "Bureij")
 in the Gaza Strip.[\[147\]](#cite_note-155)
 [Shayetet 13](/wiki/Shayetet_13 "Shayetet 13")
, a commando unit of the [Israeli Navy](/wiki/Israeli_Navy "Israeli Navy")
, carried out a strike on Hamas naval forces overnight.[\[33\]](#cite_note-tjp27oct-36)
 An Israeli [Skylark II](/wiki/Elbit_Skylark "Elbit Skylark")
 drone was shot down on the Gaza Strip.[\[148\]](#cite_note-156)

#### 28 October

Israel said that the units deployed inside the Gaza Strip the previous night were still on the ground, which marked the beginning of the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip.[\[149\]](#cite_note-157)
 The IDF announced it was "expanding ground operations" in the Gaza Strip.[\[150\]](#cite_note-158)
 The Israeli military reissued a call to Gaza residents to evacuate the north as Prime Minister [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
 said that the "second phase of the war has begun".[\[151\]](#cite_note-159)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Fars_Photo_of_Casualties_in_Gaza_Strip_during_2023_War_31.jpg/250px-Fars_Photo_of_Casualties_in_Gaza_Strip_during_2023_War_31.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fars_Photo_of_Casualties_in_Gaza_Strip_during_2023_War_31.jpg)

An injured child in the Gaza Strip amid the 2023 Israeli airstrikes.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/SoI-War_23-11-01_IDF_13-08.jpg/250px-SoI-War_23-11-01_IDF_13-08.jpg)](/wiki/File:SoI-War_23-11-01_IDF_13-08.jpg)

Israeli military during ground operations in the Gaza Strip on 1 November

The IDF advanced on three fronts: from the northeast near [Beit Hanoun](/wiki/Beit_Hanoun "Beit Hanoun")
,[\[152\]](#cite_note-160)
 from the northwest near [Beit Lahia](/wiki/Beit_Lahia "Beit Lahia")
, and from the east near [Juhor ad-Dik](/wiki/Juhor_ad-Dik "Juhor ad-Dik")
.[\[153\]](#cite_note-NYTMaps-161)

#### 29 October

[Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus](/wiki/Tedros_Adhanom_Ghebreyesus "Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus")
, the head of the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization")
 (WHO), described as "deeply concerning" reports from the [Palestine Red Crescent Society](/wiki/Palestine_Red_Crescent_Society "Palestine Red Crescent Society")
 with smoke and dust, prompting staff to give breathing masks to some patients.[\[154\]](#cite_note-BBCquds1029-162)
 Around 14,000 civilians were believed to be sheltering in or near the hospital.[\[154\]](#cite_note-BBCquds1029-162)
 The [al-Quds hospital](/wiki/Al-Quds_hospital "Al-Quds hospital")
 had received an urgent evacuation warning along with a notice that it was "going to be bombarded". An Israeli military spokesman said "The IDF was not shown any proof that this is a civilian car and there's no information on who is inside."[\[161\]](#cite_note-169)
 A kidnapped IDF [private](/wiki/Private_(rank) "Private (rank)")
 was freed the same day in an operation headed by the IDF, with assistance from [Shin Bet](/wiki/Shin_Bet "Shin Bet")
 and [Mossad](/wiki/Mossad "Mossad")
.[\[162\]](#cite_note-170)
 In northwest Gaza, the [Al-Qassam Brigades](/wiki/Izz_ad-Din_al-Qassam_Brigades "Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades")
 and the [DFLP](/wiki/DFLP "DFLP")
's [National Resistance Brigades](/wiki/National_Resistance_Brigades "National Resistance Brigades")
 engaged Israeli forces, and the National Resistance Brigades bombarded Israeli vehicles with heavy mortar shells.[\[41\]](#cite_note-usw730-44)

### November 2023

#### 1 November

IDF reported the deaths of 16 soldiers, 15 inside Gaza and one outside of Palestinian territory.[\[163\]](#cite_note-IDFcas-171)

On 2 November, IDF had completely surrounded Gaza City, which began the [siege of Gaza City](/wiki/Siege_of_Gaza_City "Siege of Gaza City")
.[\[164\]](#cite_note-WSJCutGaza-172)
[\[165\]](#cite_note-173)
 Al-Qassam Brigades showed footage of the destruction of an Israeli Merkava tank after its fighters used an [Al-Yassin 105mm](/wiki/Al-Yassin_105 "Al-Yassin 105")
 rocket-propelled grenade to neutralize its [Trophy protection system](/wiki/Trophy_(countermeasure) "Trophy (countermeasure)")
.[\[166\]](#cite_note-174)

#### 4 November

A UNRWA spokeswoman confirmed reports that Israel had conducted [an airstrike](/wiki/Al-Fakhoora_school_airstrike "Al-Fakhoora school airstrike")
 against a United Nations-run school in the Jabalia refugee camp.[\[167\]](#cite_note-ReutersUNSchool1104-175)
 According to the [Gaza Health Ministry](/wiki/Gaza_Health_Ministry "Gaza Health Ministry")
, the attack killed 15 people and wounded dozens more.[\[167\]](#cite_note-ReutersUNSchool1104-175)
 According to [UNRWA](/wiki/UNRWA "UNRWA")
, at least one strike hit the schoolyard, where displaced families had set up their tents.[\[167\]](#cite_note-ReutersUNSchool1104-175)
 The [Gaza Ministry of Health](/wiki/Gaza_Ministry_of_Health "Gaza Ministry of Health")
 said another Israeli missile strike on the entrance to the Nasser Children's Hospital killed two women.[\[167\]](#cite_note-ReutersUNSchool1104-175)
 According to White House officials, efforts to evacuate foreign nationals through the Rafah border crossing were temporarily hindered by Hamas's refusal to allow anyone to leave, until a certain number of its own wounded were also allowed to leave.[\[168\]](#cite_note-176)
[\[169\]](#cite_note-177)
 Hamas said that within the last two days they had destroyed 24 Israeli vehicles, including a tank, an APC, and a bulldozer with anti-armour weapons.[\[170\]](#cite_note-178)

Turkey recalled its ambassador to Israel "in view of the unfolding humanitarian tragedy in Gaza caused by the continuing attacks by Israel against civilians, and Israel's refusal (to accept) a ceasefire." President [Recep Tayyip Erdogan](/wiki/Recep_Tayyip_Erdogan "Recep Tayyip Erdogan")
 told reporters he held Netanyahu personally responsible for civilian deaths in Gaza and said that he was "no longer someone we can talk to".[\[171\]](#cite_note-France24Erdogan-179)

[Abu Obaida](/wiki/Abu_Obaida_(Hamas) "Abu Obaida (Hamas)")
, the spokesperson for the [Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades](/wiki/Izz_ad-Din_al-Qassam_Brigades "Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades")
, reported that due to Israeli air strikes, the bodies of 23 missing Israeli hostages were buried under the rubble.[\[172\]](#cite_note-180)
[\[173\]](#cite_note-181)

#### 5 November

IDF reported that 29 soldiers had been killed, and one severely wounded, during the fighting in the Gaza Strip.[\[174\]](#cite_note-IDFlosses11042023-182)

#### 6 November

Israeli missile attacks targeted the [Nasser Medical Complex](/wiki/Nasser_Medical_Complex "Nasser Medical Complex")
 in Gaza City, hitting the Al-Nasser Children's Hospital, eight people were killed and dozens more were injured according to [Al Jazeera](/wiki/Al_Jazeera "Al Jazeera")
.[\[175\]](#cite_note-183)
 Human Rights Watch called for a weapons embargo against both Israel and Hamas and other Palestinian militant groups, accusing them of committing war crimes against civilians.[\[176\]](#cite_note-184)

_[The Wall Street Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")
_ reported that the U.S. On 12 July, Israel was forced to retreat from areas of Gaza City it had occupied, though some snipers continued to control high ground.[\[373\]](#cite_note-381)

### August 2024

#### 31 August

The [Israeli military](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces")
 recovered the bodies of six hostages [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
 kidnapped during the [October 7 attack on Israel](/wiki/2023_Hamas-led_attack_on_Israel "2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel")
, including U.S."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article discusses the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip, which began on October 27, 2023, and is ongoing. It mentions the involvement of various military units and the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas. The article also provides a timeline of events, including ground assaults, sieges, and attacks on civilian areas. The article mentions the destruction of Israeli tanks during the invasion. The article also mentions the "Shuja'iyya ambush". The article does not mention Jabalia camp or October 2024.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:34> This image shows an Israeli tank unit near Jabalia camp in northern Gaza that was successfully ambushed by Hamas fighters, destroying multiple vehicles and injuring or killing their crews in October 2024."


## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`

The source kashif.ps discusses an old photo being circulated as showing the destruction of an Israeli military tank (<image:9605>).


### Evidence from `geolocate`
The most likely countries where the image was taken are: {'Pakistan': 0.11, 'Palestine': 0.11, 'Israel': 0.1, 'Tunisia': 0.09, 'Mexico': 0.06, 'Colombia': 0.05, 'Chile': 0.04, 'Sweden': 0.03, 'Argentina': 0.02, 'Denmark': 0.02}

## Elaboration
The image search results show other images of burning tanks, but they do not confirm the details of the claim. The geolocation data suggests the image could have been taken in Palestine or Israel, but this is not definitive. The evidence does not provide enough information to verify the claim.

The claim mentions an ambush by Hamas fighters near Jabalia camp in northern Gaza in October 2024. The evidence does not contain any information about the date, location, or the actors involved in the event.

To verify the claim, information about the specific event, including the date, location, and the parties involved, is needed.
